question: When the remains of plants and animals are covered by layers of sediment over time, what do they become?

content.source_1: Rapid burial by layers of sediment protects dead organisms from scavengers and slows decay, creating conditions that commonly lead to fossilization.
content.source_2: Mineral-rich groundwater moving through buried sediments can replace or infill tissues with minerals (permineralization), turning the remains into fossils.
content.source_3: Over geologic time, the accumulating sediments lithify into sedimentary rock, which frequently preserves the fossilized remains within its layers.
content.source_4: In acidic depositional settings (such as peat bogs or acid-sulfate soils), pore waters dissolve bone and shell material during diagenesis, so the buried remains can be destroyed before any fossil forms.
content.source_5: In highly permeable, oxygenated sands, continuous groundwater flow accelerates microbial decay and chemical dissolution of buried remains, often leaving no fossil record in those strata.
content.source_6: Deep burial that subjects sediments to elevated temperatures and pressures can metamorphose the rock and obliterate biological structures, erasing potential fossils from those layers.
